The game, when you first look at it, looks like your generic FPS with subpar graphics and near CounterStrike-like mechanics. However, when you actually get your hands on the game, you find that it's something all together different.

Something all together worse than you thought. Man, is this game a mess.

Let's weigh the pro's and con's.

Pro's
*Game is very quick to download, and likely will uninstall even faster.
*Controls are solid, and almost identical to CounterStrike, with the exception of ADS (Aiming down the sights)
*Game is rather easy to run, even on a mediocre setup, even though the game defaults to extremely low from the start.
*Game has a Bot fighting mode, which allows you to get away from the game's horrid community.
*The Knife Fight game mode is actually the game's strong point, where it is likely to be the only mode you'll have fun in.

Con's
*Game is very hit-or-miss on start-up. It will either force feed you an error, or give you a blank black screen until you close out of it and try again. Even then, it will take a few moments to get the game running to your correct resolution, and graphical choice.
*Overall gameplay is absolutely abysmal, and barely functioning.
*Gunplay feels like it's trying so desperately to be just like CounterStrike, but trying to force in elements of Call of Duty by giving the false hope of aiming down the sights of your weapons (when and only when they have scopes). In reality, it's still random if the guns will even work at all. This, topped with the fact that all guns are one-shot-kill to the head, makes for a frustrating experience no matter what map you're on, or what weapon you use.
*The maps on the game are uninspired and boring. All that really sticks out is whether they're symetrical, or asymetrcial.
*The game's overall server stability is shoddy at best. You'll be falling in and out of games.
*The spawning in this game is horrible. No matter what game mode you play, you will either be camping the enemy spawn, or are in the process of being spawn-camped, yourself. This, coupled with extraordinarily long respawn times, makes for an utterly keyboard-breakingly terrible time.
*The game's community, small as it is, is mainly dominated with young children who likely downloaded the game simply because it had female soldiers in it that you can make wear bikinis, and their constant bickering in the chat boxes in game will remind you frequently to their presence. reviewText:
Piercing Blow: Broken edition
Ever wanted a Counter Strike type of game that’s completely broken? Neither did I, but Zepetto Corporation decided the world needed another cluster♥♥♥♥ in the ever expanding library of broken videogames. Prepare for a rant, because you’re going to get one…



First Second run
Oh the first run of this game… I am not the type of person to cry, but I felt the urge to do just that this time. I think it’s best to explain this by telling you the first ten minutes I experienced with this game:

When I started the game for the first time, I got a black screen. The music started to play and I knew that the menu was actually loaded because of the sounds. So I decided to hit enter twice and guess what? That closes the game. I should have kept it closed, but I decided to give it another try and oh joy, it worked this time....in 4:3 screen format.

Now when I see a game do that, I immediately search for a settings button so I can rectify this and immediately tweak the rest of the graphical settings. But hey, why add such a button when you are in the first menu? Nah, I first needed to join a channel before I was even able to set a nickname and select a character. Still no settings button to be found.

So I selected a character, selected a gun type called ‘machine’, (because apparently that’s a gun type now) and created the character. But no no no, the game didn’t want me to use a ‘machine’ and decided to give me an assault rifle instead.

Thankfully there was a settings button now, so I figured I was past the worst part. I was not. When opening the settings I immediately noticed that you need to restart the game for more than half of the settings in that menu! Luckily the developers were so kind to leave out half of the important stuff so I did not have to bother with more than 15 popups saying I needed to restart. Thank you developers, that’s very kind of you /s.

So after all this time, all I achieved was getting a nickname (for which you are required to manually click the namecheck button somehow), creating a character that was not even the same as what I got after I created it and changing my resolution and some other settings. Remember I said ten minutes? That was ten minutes.

Are you crying yet? No? Let me tell you a little story about gameplay then…



Gameplay
After clicking through a couple of floating coins and ignoring 17000 join requests (thanks again devs, I really like that you added a random invite button there), I finally got into a game. And boy is it broken.

When playing a match in this game, you will immediately notice similarities with Counter Strike and that should be a good thing. Except it is not anywhere near as good as CS. The game types are pretty similar and when you are dead, you need to wait until the next round. That much is okay about this game. What is not is the fact that it is unbalanced as hell! Sure, there is some kind of hack detection present in the game, but since some weapons are extremely OP, you can expect lots of kiddies whining about HAXXX nonetheless. Oh and when you áre able to respawn, you can expect the entire enemy team to be standing at your spawn point, ready to blow your head off after you lose invulnerability.

I don’t think I even need to go any further on that subject as this should basically be enough to stop you from playing it already.



Micro transactions
While I am not a fan of this system, I normally accept the fact that it is present in a Free2Play title. Developers have to earn their money some way, right?

While this game does not really have ridiculously high prices for their micro transactions, they stuff you buy with it is extremely pricey which means you have to buy a lot stuff anyway. Well, technically the items are not that pricey, but if you have to rebuy them EVERY 24 HOURS that’s still going to suck up all the coins you bought in no time.



Conclusion
I have seen some bad videogames over the years now, but this one is really somewhere on the top of that list. The developers claim it won some prices in Thailand for Best Casual Game in 2011 and say that the world ‘raves about this game’, but obviously that’s just fake. This game is a complete cluster♥♥♥♥ that starts making you angry before you even enter your first match.

While the game does seem very well optimized and is functional in some areas, it screws up on so many levels that I cannot possible give this a rating higher than a

2/10

Please, if you install this game, only install it so you can hit the uninstall button. That’s the only satisfying experience you will get from it.

reviewText:
its very hard to decide if i want to recommend or not recommend this game because it is free to play, so i can't really say where the line is on that.  here's a few points that might be of interest to future players.

GRAPHICS:  the graphics aren't very good in this game, but run quite nicely.  it is very smooth, but not very detailed

PLAYERS:  the other players in the game don't have a huge effect on your experience.  they try to complete the objectives and don't say much.  its actually relaxing to not have a constant feed of BS going through mics or chat lines.

PAY TO WIN:  this game is very pay to win oriented.  without spending some hard-earned cash CONSTANTLY, you are pretty much sitting downhill from everyone else.  the reason i say its constant is because everything in game only lasts for a little while before it expires and you have to get new gear or deal with the original equipment.

GAMEPLAY:  the gameplay is that of an early 2000's game.  its bad, but not painfully so.  melee is really the kicker for me on that.  you have to press a key to switch to your melee weapon before you can use it, then switch back to your gun with another key.  plus, the melee weapons that are free, suck.  they take two hits and its rediculously hard to hit anyone with them.  the paid weapons are one hit kills.

MAPS:  the maps are extremely small and they are not detailed at all.  they work for the game, but with anything bigger than like a 6 on 6, would be just too many people on too small of an area.  they are similar to the size of nuketown 2025 on BlackOps II.

WEAPONS:  the weapons are decent.  they work, but unless you have a scope, you can't look down the sights, which was one of the most frustrating aspects of this game for me.  accuracy SUCKED.  weapons are also very pay to win oriented.

MENU:  the menu sucked but worked.  it was frustrating to have everything cost money.  the entire menu was just low quality, but it got the job done and wasn't lagging at all.

hope this review helped you future piercing blow gamers.

reviewText:
Piercing Blow (PB) is one of the latest free to play FPS games to be released to the Steam store. It's already gathered a large amount of negative reviews and after playing the game for less than 20 minutes I could already see why.

Let's begin with the main menu. The menu you are greeted with is very minimalist which in most cases is usually a good thing and generally makes the game more user-friendly, but in the case of PB less is not good. From the main menu screen you can see your stats (such as kills, deaths, wins and losses), you can a access a browser that allows you to join open channels for matches in game and you can shut down you game. That's it for the main menu. One glaring issue is the lack of an options menu for changing your video, audio, control and general games settings. This should not be an issue even in a free to play title such as PB, also a large amount of the options on the main menu are blocked and in accessible to the user. These options become accessible once you select a channel to join along with the games options menu. One question that needs to be asked is “Why aren't these options available to us on the main menu?” Especially the game’s options menu. The options provided in the main menu are reasonable for a free to play game.

Now that the main menu is covered let's move onto the gameplay. The gameplay wasn't as bad as I expected it be. The controls were easy to use. It feels like a FPS and plays like one it's just when I play it I can't help but feel like I've seen it before. It's pretty clear from the way the levels and some of the gamemodes are designed that this game took alot of inspiration from Counter-Strike Source, however it seems like PB is just a free to play clone of CS:S and not a unique title.

Another point that needs to be addressed is the inventory menu. At least from my experience this menu is very glitchy and I found myself stuck in the menu alot without any way of getting out. Also when I open up the game after shutting it down for some reason my loadout reverts to the default and I have to reequip my weapons all over again.

Throughout the review I have not mentioned the games graphics yet, this is because the game was originally released in 2007 and since then there have been many improvements in the way graphics have been designed it would be unfair to judge it based on today’s standards. However for a game that was released 3 years after CS:S I have to say the graphics look worse than the graphics in CS:S. It seems that the only parts of the game that are designed well from a graphical standpoint are the character models and weapons. I would have expected the game to have had decent map textures for a game released in 2007 and just shows how little attention to detail the developers had for the games graphics.

Overall, this game looks like it was put on steam as a re-release to help boost the game’s player population, but has very few unique qualities that would make it an entertaining FPS. The game borrows a lot of ideas from Counter Strike: Source, but does not develop upon these ideas at all. Piercing Blow is a very good example what a free to play FPS should not be like and the developers should learn from the mistakes made with this game.

reviewText:
Coming from a user who started playing this game in 2010 on the stand-alone client.

Pros
1. Hit register never fails. If you didn't get the shot you missed.. period.
2. Doesn't take a lot of time to get in to the groove of the game, but mastering it takes much longer.
3. Can run on low-end (2011-2012 amd/nvidia chipsets ) PC's perfectly on high/medium settings.
4. There is always some kind of event or give away.
5. As you rank up, you receive items to help you throughout your experience.
6. There is missions/quests to help you rank up faster, so less time worrying about how low your rank is.
7. Built-in enhancement system for your character(s) (You can pick more than one character). These enhancements are class-chosen (Assault Rifler, SMG, Sniper) and so on. The enhancements are things like accuracy, firing your gun faster, reloading faster, throwing grenades farther, so on.
8. A fresh experience for a player who has played common FPS's.
9. It has a tutorial that gives you free in-game points.

Cons
1. Poor in-game recording tool. You will be better off using tools like Fraps and ShadowPlay.
2. Slightly P2W, but you can easily destroy enemies who have equipped pay-to-win items.
3. The game mechanics a majority of the time are highly unrealistic, compared to games like CS:GO. Please don't say this game is a copy of CS:GO, dear god it was released 5 years before GO.
4. Extremely limited PVE mode. It is a deathmatch mode where you can go up to vs. 8 bots, and the more kills you get, the higher their difficulty increases.
5. The weapons are not permanent in any way. There is quanity (guns purchased with points) and days (equipment purchased with points/ real money or guns purchased with real money). The default set options for these gun purchases I believe are 1 day, 3 days, and 1 month. You can buy more days, but these are the defaults.

reviewText:
This is an old(ish) free to play game that went by multiple names, I knew this game as Project Blackout, that was its name in North America almost over six years ago. Back in Korea, its place of conception, this was known as Point Blank. Reception to the game was relatively warm.

I can tell you why it received some warm thoughts back then, and that's because the guns were varied, the character models were surprisingly detailed at the time; and the maps had some interesting gimmicks going on. We had toasters at the time and we didn't have to bug our parents to buy the game for us.

Other free-to-play games at the time were Crossfire, Soldier Front and WolfTeam. But Project Blackout/Piercing Blow was a lot slicker in its presentation.

Piercing Blow and the games that I mentioned are all F2P Korean FPSes. They were all developed on the cheap, they were cheap for the consumer, and the publishers got signifigant returns. They sought to mimic popular titles and in this case it was Counter-Strike 1.6 and Source. You had to pay for those games. In some parts of the world, this wasn't an option - especially in South America and other places where games are a massive luxury. Thanks for to free to play games, they were offered an alternative. For a game to be successful in Korea, it had to be free, so don't confuse this for them trying to directly advertise towards anybody else.

And that's partially why these games are dying, CS 1.6 and Source are considered relics and tastes have changed. Kids don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about Source, and they sure as hell won't touch 1.6.

Korean free-to-play shooters aren't doing very well and this is all thanks to fatigue given to us by AAA publishers. If its not the fatigue that bothers the casual player, then it might be the dated presentation that this game now has to offer. If you look at the other reviews, most of them will mention its graphics - blissfully unaware of the game's age and overall purpose.

Mainstream tastes generally forecast the future of these games. If the forecast is bleak, then you're in trouble. It's simply the dangerous life of riding off of the coattails. If the person wearing the coat dies, then those on the coattails have no success to ride off of.

Regardless, A game that's free to play is pretty hard to make money off of without being creative. Especially if its older and lacks the refinement of big-budget free to play games today, so its only natural that the game is pay-to-win. At one point, when the game was named Project Blackout, this wasn't a huge problem. Now, its a game-breaking issue.

Weapon synergy is dead in this game, back in the day, you'd actually see people with Sniper Rifles doing their thing, and shotguns were an often occurance. But now, you only see people with Golden P90s. Premium SMGs have godlike spread and accuracy with a seemingly never ending magazine. If you want to win, then pull out your credit card and buy yourself a golden P90. If you're not gonna buy a P90, then don't expect to win confrontations very often.

The game has little to no lag compensation, so because of this the player is forced to lead their shots. But what really sucks is the fact that there's no numerical latency values, so you can never be too sure of how far you should shoot ahead. (if you're dealing with a person that has 500ms of lag, you'll know to aim around a half of a second ahead.) I can't really blame the game for this, because it has no control over who decides to pick up and play. Unless they decide to do an IP block against South American nations (which a game actually decided to do, I just forgot which one.)

Occasionally, fun can be had, but its often shortlived. What we're seeing is a Korean Free-to-play game at its end of life/endgame, festering to the brim with guns that have tattoo art (actually not far off from CSGO, although F2p games have been doing skins of guns for way longer); golden guns having statistical advantages over their non-shiny counter parts; and cosmetics that give you an advantage.

Stay away from this game. This game doesn't have fun as one of its intentions, it prefers money.

This game is published by Zepetto U.S.A, which is interesting as Zepetto were the guys who actually developed this game.

I WARN YOU, WHATEVER EXCITING THING YOU THOUGHT THIS GAME WAS, IT ISN'T.
